hikes.description: This trail starts on the Pulliam Creek Trail off of SR 1802. After half a mile, you'll notice wooden boards leading down to a waterfall on the left. There's also a nice camping area on the right approximately three-quarters of a mile down the trail. Continue south on this trail until you reach an intersection. The Pulliam Trail continues south and east and veers left. Veer right down a steep and slippery trail to the foot of the Green River Narrows. The trail is marked by pink ribbons.

hikes.name: Chestnut Ridge Heritage Preserve Trail
hikes.description: This trail weaves upward through the Chestnut Ridge Heritage Preserve eventually reaching the South Pacolet River.

hikes.name: The Pinnacle via Ridgeline Trail and Boulders Access
hikes.description: Discover this 11.3-mile out-and-back trail near Kings Mountain, North Carolina. Generally considered a challenging route, it takes an average of 5 h 22 min to complete. This is a popular trail for hiking and running, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

hikes.name: Crowders Trail to Rocktop Trail Loop
hikes.description: Take a hike to the summit of Crowders Mountain and you will be rewarded with breathtaking views of the surrounding landscape. This is an ideal spot for birdwatching or taking some beautiful photos of the wildflowers in bloom. Although the summit is not very high, it offers spectacular panoramic views, including a glimpse of the Charlotte skyline on the horizon.

hikes.name: Rocktop and Backside Loop
hikes.description: The Rocktop Trail is a less-traveled path that offers excellent views. Although it has a lower elevation than the Crowders summit, it provides excellent views of the cliffs and surrounding countryside. The trail presents a challenging workout with rocky terrain and uphill sections. It is an ideal choice for bird-watching, with hawks frequently spotted. While the loop section of the trail can be crowded, there are secluded spots to explore by climbing around the rocks.

hikes.name: Company Mill Trail to Reedy Creek Trail Loop
hikes.description: Try this 6.0-mile loop trail near Raleigh, North Carolina. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 2 h 21 min to complete. This is a very popular area for hiking and walking, so you'll likely encounter other people while exploring.

hikes.name: Sycamore Trail
hikes.description: Although there are no breathtaking scenic views or towering mountains, the trail is a pleasant walk through the woods. Located right next to Raleigh, the park offers a perfect escape from the city's hustle-bustle.

hikes.name: Campbell Creek and Lanier Falls Loop Trail
hikes.description: Raven Rock State Park is off of Hwy 421 between Sanford and Lillington, NC.  The park is best known for its namesake rock - Raven Rock. The Campbell Creek/Lanier Falls Trails are about 5 1/2 miles when combined and can be completed in 2-4 hours.

hikes.name: Bald Head Island Forest Preserve Loop Trail
hikes.description: Enjoy this 3.0-mile loop trail near Southport, North Carolina. Generally considered an easy route. This trail is great for hiking, running, and walking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. The trail is open year-round and is beautiful to visit anytime. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash

hikes.name: Weetock Trail
hikes.description: The trail begins just off the highway, with no specific parking area, only a small pulloff. The first part of the trail is easy to follow and well-marked. However, once you get past Haywood Landing, the trail becomes less traveled. The markers become less frequent, and the path is less defined. Additionally, you will have to navigate undermaintained wooden bridges. Once you reach the next road, pay close attention to the map.

hikes.name: Oak Island Beach Walk
hikes.description: This is a lightly trafficked walk along the beautiful beach from the lighthouse towards the pier. The majority of this beach walk is exposed and bringing sun protection is advised.

hikes.name: Lower China Creek
hikes.description: This is an unmaintained route that travels along a forest road as well as a primitive single-track trail. The China Creek Trail is not traveled often so it is a bit overgrown in parts, especially during the summer months. There is no cell phone service in the area, and it is suggested to download the offline map ahead of time. There are some unauthorized ropes anchored to get down to the falls- please use at your own discretion. The first part of the trail is gorgeous and between the river and forest views, you can't beat this hike. Make sure to take a dip in the falls when the weather is warm!

hikes.name: China Creek Trail to Thunderhole Falls
hikes.description: This trail is great for waterfall lovers, as there are many scattered throughout the way on China Creek Trail. The main attraction is Thunderhole Falls. This is a challenging trail that is not frequented much by others. It is steep going down and steep going back up. Beautiful mature trees line the way and once you arrive at the gap, the stream is spectacular.

hikes.name: Buckeye Loop Trail
hikes.description: This is an unmaintained route that has no signs and can be challenging to navigate at certain points. The trail mostly follows old service roads which can be overgrown. There are several horse camps and campgrounds that you will pass along the route. There are no mountain views on this trail, but there is an abundance of wildlife to observe.

hikes.name: Pemetic North and South Ridge Trails
hikes.description: The hike begins at Bubble Pond and traverses the ridge of Pemetic Mountain before reaching Jordan Pond.

hikes.name: Triad and Pemetic East Cliff Trails
hikes.description: Users will climb the south ridge of The Triad up to the summit of Pemetic Mountain via the Pemetic East Cliffs and Pemetic South Ridge Trails.

hikes.name: Hadlock Ponds, Parkman Mountain and Maple Spring Trail
hikes.description: This hike begins with a nice walk along the shore of Hadlock Pond before climbing up Parkman Mountain. Enjoy the views from the summit of Parkman Mountain and Gilmore Peak before the steep descent down the Maple Spring Trail.

hikes.name: Russell Pond to South Branch Pond Campground via Pogy Notch Trail
hikes.description: Discover this 8.7-mile point-to-point trail near Mount Chase, Maine. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 3 h 11 min to complete. This trail is great for backpacking, camping, and hiking, and it's unlikely you'll encounter many other people while exploring. You'll need to leave pups at home — dogs aren't allowed on this trail.

hikes.name: Mount Katahdin via Hunt Trail
hikes.description: The Hunt Trail begins in the forest and then begins a very rocky climb up to the summit of Mount Katahdin.

hikes.name: Chimney Pond Trail
hikes.description: Check out this 6.3-mile out-and-back trail near Millinocket, Maine. Generally considered a moderately challenging route, it takes an average of 3 h 21 min to complete. This is a very popular area for backpacking, camping, and hiking, so you'll likely encounter other people while exploring. The best times to visit this trail are May through October. You'll need to leave pups at home — dogs aren't allowed on this trail.

hikes.name: Old Speck Mountain Trail
hikes.description: Just east of the New Hampshire border, this is Maine's 4th highest mountain and 5th highest peak. It's the highest and most northeastern peak in the Mahoosuc Range of the White Mountains.

hikes.name: Haystack Notch Trail
hikes.description: From route 113, this trail passes into the Speckled Mountain Wilderness and the base of Caribou Mountain, Haystack Mountain, and along the west branch of Pleasant River.

hikes.name: Baldface Circle Trail
hikes.description: This is a loop hike with several fun stream crossings and a lot of views at the top of both peaks and along the ridge.  As their name implies, both peaks have bald summits and in some steep places you may find yourself on fun scrambles.  There will be fantastic views on clear days towards the taller White Mountains including Mt. Washington which dominates the horizon.

hikes.name: Tumbledown Mountain Trail
hikes.description: This trail is not recommended for dogs due to the presence of a ladder and multiple sections that may require you to lift your dog. Loop trail is a bit strenuous and much more technical (Hiking over large rocks and climbing up through cavernous boulders).

hikes.name: Cranberry Peak via Currie Road
hikes.description: At just short of 3,000 feet, Cranberry Peak still has a rocky and exposed summit with views of the Bigelow Range ridge line, and the numerous surrounding mountains and lakes.

hikes.name: Saddleback Mountain and The Horn from Ski Lodge
hikes.description: The start is from the base of the ski slope and is steep in spots, but the views from Saddleback to The Horn are incredible. Hiking up the ski slopes is not permitted during the ski season.

hikes.name: Ocean Lookout via Nature Trail Loop
hikes.description: Begin from the trailhead off Mount Battie Road and start on the Nature Trail. The trail is named after all of the native plants that can be spotted along the trail. The route then meets up with the Tablelands Trail leading to the Ocean Lookout and then descending the Megunticook Trail.

hikes.name: Barred Island Preserve Trail
hikes.description: This trail leads through a spruce forest filled with moss covered rocks leading to a small rocky and sandy beach.

hikes.name: Western Head via Goat Trail
hikes.description: This trail leading to Western Head does a great job highlighting the rugged coast of Acadia National Park. Isle Au Haut is true gem of Acadia, this is a place visitors to the park will experience true solitude and peace.

hikes.name: Borestone Mountain Trail
hikes.description: Very well maintained trail. The first half is a wooded trail with a moderate incline. The top has some somewhat challenging climbing above the tree line. Absolutely fabulous views on top.

hikes.name: Gulf Hagas Rim Trail and Pleasant River Tote
hikes.description: Gulf Hagas is known as the Grand Canyon of Maine and this loop has great views of the rocky gorge. Begin on the Appalachian Trail and then follow the Pleasant River Tote Road. Take the Rim Trail past Stair Falls, Billings Falls, Buttermilk Falls, and Screw Auger Falls. There are also several other overlooks looking over the Pleasant River.
hikes.location: Appalachian Mountain Club 100 Mile Wilderness Conservation Area

hikes.name: Little Wilson Falls
hikes.description: Follow a blue blaze trail along Little Wilson Stream to the unique waterfall. The road can be muddy, so there is a waypoint included with parking instructions if the road is in bad condition.
hikes.location: Appalachian Mountain Club 100 Mile Wilderness Conservation Area

hikes.name: Mackworth Island Hiking Trail
hikes.description: As you walk the trail you will see many beautiful views of Portland and the nearby islands in Casco Bay. There are at least 6 access trails leading down to the rocky beaches. The island is considered a bird sanctuary.

hikes.name: Eastern Trail: Scarborough to Saco
hikes.description: Try this 9.3-mile point-to-point trail near Scarborough, Maine. Generally considered an easy route, it takes an average of 2 h 48 min to complete. This is a popular trail for birding, cross-country skiing, and fishing, but you can still enjoy some solitude during quieter times of day. The best times to visit this trail are March through October. Dogs are welcome, but must be on a leash.

hikes.name: Malaga Island Preserve Trail
hikes.description: Accessible by boat only.  Beautiful island public preserve protected by the Maine Coast Heritage Trust. Malaga Island is an important Maine historical site, with a kiosk and markers that provide information about the community that once lived on the island. The one mile loop nature trail winds through a variety of habitats, including a few small salt marshes, woods, and rocky coast.
